title: Student 'drove boyfriend to kill himself in text messages saying "go die"'
text:

A young woman drove her depressed boyfriend to take his own life as she bombarded him with text messages urging him to "go die" and "go kill yourself", it is claimed.

Inyoung You, 21, allegedly told Alexander Urtula, 22, the “world would be better without him” and was present when he jumped to his death in May.

Mr Urtula, a biology major at Boston College in the US, died less than two hours before he was due to receive his diploma at a graduation ceremony.

You, who has been charged with involuntary manslaughter, and Mr Urtula exchanged 75,000 text messages in the two months before his death, with his girlfriend allegedly telling him thousands of times to kill himself.

(Image: Suffolk County District Attorney)

During their 18-month relationship, You was controlling, tracked Mr Urtula's movements through his mobile phone and sent about 47,000 texts in the months before he died, according to investigators.

She is accused of isolating Mr Urtula from his family and friends, psychologically and physically abusing him, and using threats of self-harm to control and manipulate him.

You allegedly bombarded him with more than 780 "manipulative and threatening" text messages every day, the Boston Herald reported.

Suffolk County District Attorney Rachael Rollins told reporters: “You’s behaviour was wanton and reckless and resulted in overwhelming Mr Urtula’s will to live."

The prosecutor added: "She was aware of his spiralling depression and suicidal thoughts brought on by her abuse.

(Image: Suffolk County District Attorney)

"Yet she persisted, continuing to encourage him to take his own life."

Economics student You left Boston College and returned to her native South Korea a few months after her partner's death.

Prosecutors said she will be extradited to the US if she does not voluntarily return to face the charges.

If convicted, she could be sentenced to up to 20 years in prison.

You's text messages became "more frequent, powerful and demeaning" over time, Ms Rollins said.

She added: "We have a barrage, a complete and utter attack on this man's very will and conscious and psyche by an individual to the tune of 40,000 text messages in the two months leading up."

Prosecutors claim You stalked Mr Urtula, from Cedar Grove, New Jersey, to the multi-storey car park where he died and was present when he jumped to his death.

Mr Urtula's parents had travelled to suburban Boston, Massachusetts, that day to watch him accept his diploma.

Ms Rollins told reporters: "A perpetrator is not limited by their gender or the gender of their partner.

"Domestic violence may not always look the same, but it is always about power and control."

description: Inyoung You, 21, has been charged after she allegedly bombarded Boston College student Alexander Urtula, 22, with 47,000 texts, including messages telling him to "go die" and "go kill yourself"
